title: 108_hr4522
content: The "International Space Station Independent Safety Commission Act of 2004" establishes a Commission to oversee safety measures for the International Space Station (ISS). Key definitions include terms like Commission, ISS, NASA, NASA Administrator, and NTSB. Establishment of an independent, nonpartisan Commission within the executive branch to assess vulnerabilities of the International Space Station that could jeopardize its safety or necessitate its abandonment. The President must establish the Commission within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission consists of 15 members, with the Chairman of the NTSB being a member. The President appoints the remaining 14 members, including the Chairman and Vice Chairman. Five members are selected by the President based on recommendations from key Senate and House leaders, as well as the President of the largest NASA engineers' collective-bargaining organization. The President appoints 14 members to the 15-member Commission, with recommendations from key Senate and House leaders, as well as the President of the largest NASA engineers' collective-bargaining organization. No federal government officers or employees can serve on the Commission, and members cannot have a contractual relationship with NASA. The President can waive these prohibitions for up to 2 members. Members cannot have a current or former relationship with the NASA Administrator. The President appoints 14 members to the Commission, ensuring diversity and relevant experience. All members must be appointed within 60 days of the executive order, and the Commission will meet as soon as possible after formation. Meetings will be called by the Chairman or a majority of members after the initial meeting. The Commission shall meet upon the call of the Chairman or a majority of its members, with eight members constituting a quorum. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission is tasked with cataloging threats and vulnerabilities to the ISS, making recommendations for corrective actions, providing important findings or recommendations, and preparing a report for Congress, the President, and the public. The Commission has the power to meet upon the call of the Chairman or a majority of its members, with eight members constituting a quorum. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission, or any subcommittee or member authorized by the Commission, may hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, administer oaths, and issue subpoenas to compel witness testimony and document production for the purpose of carrying out the Act. Subpoenas under this subsection can only be issued by the agreement of the Chairman and Vice Chairman or by the affirmative vote of 8 Commission members. Subpoenas may be signed by the Chairman or a designated member and served by a designated person. Enforcement measures are in place for cases of contumacy. In cases of contumacy or failure to obey a subpoena, the United States district court can issue an order for the person to testify or produce evidence. Failure to comply may result in contempt of court. Additional enforcement measures are available for witnesses who fail to comply. The Commission can certify a witness's failure to comply with a subpoena to the United States attorney for possible grand jury action. Additionally, the Commission has the authority to enter into contracts as provided in appropriation Acts. The Commission can obtain information from federal agencies to fulfill its duties under the Act by requesting data, estimates, and statistics directly from various government entities as authorized by law. The Commission can obtain information from federal agencies for its tasks, with the General Services Administration providing administrative support on a reimbursable basis. Other US departments and agencies can also offer services, funds, facilities, staff, and support to the Commission. The Commission can utilize services, funds, facilities, staff, and support from federal agencies as authorized by law. The NASA Engineering and Safety Center will provide data and technical support upon request. The Commission is allowed to use the United States mails like other government departments and agencies. SEC. 7. PUBLIC MEETINGS, INFORMATION, AND HEARINGS. The Commission will hold public meetings and release public versions of required reports. Public hearings will be conducted in a manner consistent with information protection requirements. SEC. 8. STAFF OF COMMISSION. The Chairman, with the Vice Chairman's consultation, can appoint staff and set their compensation without following certain provisions of the United States Code. NASA employees cannot be appointed to the staff. Employees of NASA cannot be appointed to the staff of the Commission. The executive director and personnel of the Commission are considered federal employees. Federal Government employees, excluding NASA employees, can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Commission may procure consultant services. The Commission may procure consultant services from experts and consultants at rates not exceeding those of a level IV position in the Executive Schedule. Consultants must disclose any contracts or associations with NASA or its contractors. SEC. 9. COMPENSATION AND TRAVEL EXPENSES. Members of the Commission may receive compensation not exceeding the daily rate of pay for a level IV position in the Executive Schedule. They are also entitled to travel expenses while performing Commission duties. SEC. 10. SECURITY CLEARANCES FOR COMMISSION MEMBERS AND STAFF. SEC. 10. Security clearances will be provided to Commission members and staff by Federal agencies. Access to classified information requires appropriate security clearances. The Commission may submit interim and final reports to the President and Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The final report must include minority views. The Commission and its authorities will terminate 60 days after submitting the final report. The Commission may use the 60-day period after submitting the final report for concluding its activities, including testifying to Congress and disseminating the final report. The NASA Administrator must arrange for a National Academy of Sciences review of compliance with the Commission's recommendations, with a report due to Congress within 18 months of the final report submission. SEC. 12. FUNDING. Sums necessary for this Act are authorized to be appropriated and will remain available until the Commission's termination.
